> From: Vladimir Bossicard [mailto:vbossica@...] 
> 
> When I read the code for the new version, I noticed the 
> following line in the
> ReloadingTestSuiteLoader:
> 
>         Thread.currentThread().setContextClassLoader( loader );
> 
> I don't know if this is the cause of your problem, but it's 
> worth trying recompiling the 3.8 without this line and see 
> what happens.


Most factory methods that use a classloader rely on the context
classloader being set.  The reason is that if they are smart,
they will try to use the current thread's context classloader.

Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader().loadClass( className
).newInstance();


If you remove that method you could potentially screw up those methods.

Then again if jUnit and whatever J2EE server are both setting the thread
context classloader then there is a problem.  Someone has to use the
other classloader as a parent.

What would be smart is if jUnit would create its classloader using the
current thread context classloader as the parent--then set the context
classloader.  Then the two classloaders should be compatible.
